thread.title: Wildcats fall flat for fourth straight game in loss to Longhorns
thread.title_full: Wildcats fall flat for fourth straight game in loss to Longhorns - KCTV5

author: Posted by Laura McCallister, Multimedia Producer
title: Wildcats fall flat for fourth straight game in loss to Longhorns
text:
AUSTIN, TX (FOOTBALLKC) - After being shutout a week ago against the Oklahoma Sooners, the Kansas State Wildcats struggled again to score Saturday in a 16-9 defeat at the hands of the Texas Longhorns.
Kansas State scuffled for just 107 passing yards on the day and Deante Burton was the only Wildcat receiver to make more than a single catch.
“We are very limited in the passing game,” coach Bill Snyder said after the defeat.
The lack of offense for the Wildcats comes after K-State collapsed against third-ranked TCU in week 5 of the college football season. Since leading the Horned Frogs 35-17 at halftime, the Wildcats have mustered just 19 points in their last 10 quarters.
Quarterback Joe Hubener, making his sixth start of the season, threw for just 97 yards with one touchdown and an interception, while adding 18 yards rushing.
Hubener held his own in Kansas State’s first three games of the season, leading the team to a 3-0 record, but has looked overmatched in the team’s four consecutive losses. With Kansas State needing three more wins to become bowl eligible, Snyder may look to backup quarterbacks Jesse Ertz, Alex Delton or Jonathan Banks to take the reins of the low scoring offense.
The Wildcats were actually very productive on the ground against the Longhorns with leading rusher Charles Jones running for 122 yards on 18 carries, compiling one his most productive games on the season.
The K-State defense held their own as well, keeping versatile Texas quarterback Jerrod Heard to 160 total yards. Heard entered the game leading the Longhorns in both passing and rushing yards, but was unable to get anything going against a stout Kansas State defense.
The Wildcat defense was essentially beaten by one player, Longhorn backup quarterback Tyrone Swoopes. Swoopes scored all three touchdowns for Texas while rushing for 50 yards on seven carries.
The Wildcats will need to rebound quickly if they’re going to make a run at a bowl game in 2015. Needing three more wins to become bowl eligible, Kansas State will have to find a way to win the majority of their five remaining in-conference battles. That slate will begin the first week of November against the Baylor Bears, as the Wildcats will have time to consider all their options during their upcoming bye week.
